Louis Zamperini.Action: Jokes with a crewmate, teasing him about confusing women.
Communicates clearly and cooperatively with his crew during a stressful bombing mission.
Quietly acknowledges the enemy target before bombing ('There you are...'), showing focus and determination.
Grabs a photo taped to the broken glass and jams it in his pocket amidst chaos, indicating attachment and personal sentiment.
Lines up targets carefully and makes a perfect bomb drop destroying key enemy installations.
Remains composed under heavy enemy fire, reacts quickly to threats inside the exposed bombardier bubble.
Grabs and pockets a photo taped inside the bombardier bubble despite the chaos, showing presence of mind.
Races toward injured Harry, pulls him to safety, stabilizes and administers morphine under fire.
Notices and acknowledges the efforts of Mac and Douglass fighting despite injuries.
Looks down at the wounded Zero spiraling away, showing awareness of violence but no explicit emotional reaction.
Enters cockpit and reports concern for injured comrade Harry, saying 'Everyone’s shot up. Not sure Harry’s gonna make it.'
Looks back into damaged plane with light streaming through bullet holes, contemplative but no direct interpersonal interaction shown.

Enters the cockpit after combat and immediately assesses the situation by noting the gunner's injuries and the aircraft's hydraulic failures, asks for critical information about distance to base and runway length.
Looks back into the damaged plane, observing details like light through bullet holes and smoke, showing situational awareness and cautious evaluation.
Relays concern about crew member Harry's condition, indicating empathy but also shows concern without apparent panic, reflecting composed leadership under stress.
Looks from one parent to the other and then up at the priest, showing attentiveness and contemplation during the lesson on forgiveness and love toward enemies.
Endures being smacked by his father and the reproving gestures without visible resentment or outburst.
Displays some distraction and inattentiveness during the priest’s lesson, looking around at various objects and getting smacked by his father for misbehaving.
Eventually focuses attention on the large Christ crucified, showing ability to redirect focus.
Responds promptly and runs when Officer Collier calls out to him, showing alertness and quick reaction.
Protects and preserves his stash carefully, showing responsibility and trustworthiness with his belongings.
Engages in physical fight and uses ethnic slurs against bullies.
Maintains defiance and resilience despite being attacked, showing courage but no explicit friendliness or tolerance.
Fights aggressively with Nicky, swinging wildly.
Remains stoic and does not argue while being spanked by his father.
Does not explain or justify his actions regarding the liquor bottle when questioned.
Listens quietly to his mother’s prayers for him, showing attention and implicit trust.
Watches others from a hidden spot under the bleachers, indulging in secret cigarettes and observing the scene stealthily.
Looks at his father defiantly while his mother is heartbroken and concerned.
Observes the track team and hides under the bleachers with secret stashes like cigarettes and gum, displaying a mix of stealth and planning.
Listens to his mother praying and sets his jaw, suggesting internal resolve although no immediate action is taken.
Understands his father's anger and complicated feelings but does not intervene or react assertively.
Expresses self-doubt and insecurity about his abilities, admits 'I’m nothing,' showing vulnerability and openness to his brother Pete.
Responds honestly and vulnerably in a close relationship, allowing Pete to encourage him, indicating trust and sincerity.
Initially reluctant and pessimistic about joining the track team, showing low self-esteem but not rejecting support or friendship.
Louie runs away quickly when startled, showing physical capability and a quick reactive response.
Louie admits his own discouragement and doubt, saying he can’t make the track team and doesn’t believe in himself.
Louie overcomes initial hesitation and starts running steadily again, beginning to find his rhythm after encouragement from Pete.
Runs with determination despite a mocking grin from another runner.
Focuses on his own performance, ignoring the taunt rather than responding with hostility.
Despite starting near the back of the field and being mocked by another runner, Louie regains focus, increases his effort, overtakes competitors, and finishes strong toward the tape.
Initially running near the back and losing ground to others before waking up and picking up his pace.
Waves at his family after winning races and acknowledges the crowd's cheers.
Seems unsure of the attention from the beautiful young blonde and media flashes.
Continues to focus on the race despite being boxed in and physically fouled by competitors.
Leads and wins the first and second mile races convincingly, showing strong racing strategy, confidence, and speed.
Keeps composure and continues to gain on the leading pack in the third race despite being boxed in and physically impeded.
Reacted to physical fouling (foot stomped, shin raked) by attempting to move outside the pack to regain position.
Gives his brother a hug and thanks him sincerely before leaving.
Responds to Pete's teasing about not winning with a good-natured attitude.
Holds the parachute cords tightly while preparing to crash land and remains engaged and tense during the landing sequence.
Loses grip of the parachute ripcords during the chaotic landing.
Shares a moment of silence upon realizing Harry is dead.
Approaches Phil, notices his prayerful attitude, and sits with him respectfully.
Successfully lands a heavily damaged plane in a dangerous and unstable situation, preventing further disaster.
Approaches fallen comrade Harry and acknowledges his death with a moment of silence, showing situational awareness and emotional composure.
Walks over to Phil who is praying, and engages with him calmly and respectfully despite recent trauma.
Shares a smile with Cup after running the timed mile.
Responds to Cup's comment with a smile and a lighthearted joke about the Olympics being canceled because they heard he was coming.
Runs with increasing speed over a measured mile, accelerates strongly at the end, maintains awareness of surroundings and communicates smoothly with Cup and others.
Smiles confidently about the cancellation of the Tokyo Olympics and his readiness for competition despite the setback.
Looks at the new young faces in the crew with suspicion but quickly engages in light banter with Cup.
Drops the binoculars, blinks, then retries looking with binoculars, showing his focus and resilience but no obvious friendliness.
Orders crew to get into crash positions and instructs others to radio their position amidst crash preparations.
Prioritizes survival and assists others by dragging a pack of supplies and sitting behind bulkhead to protect himself and perhaps others.
Notices and smiles back at a Japanese athlete who smiles at him during the Olympics.
Observes a handsome African American teammate with focus and respect.
Focuses intently during the Olympic event, calmly taking a deep breath before the race.
Observes his surroundings with awareness, noting flags, other athletes, and the atmosphere of the stadium.
Smiles back at a Japanese athlete, showing social composure and confidence in an intimidating international setting.
Competes in the Olympic 5000 meter race, pacing himself with steady breathing and maintaining effort despite not leading the race.
Maintains steady breathing and composure while running despite fatigue and falling behind initially.
Hears encouragement (Pete murmuring) and responds by increasing effort and speed.
Loses position mid-race and begins to fade back among competitors.
Overtakes leading runners in Olympic race, pushes past record-breakers, and wins the race demonstrating physical and strategic skill.
Manages to conserve some energy ('gas in reserve') during race, showing intelligent pacing.
Struggles to free himself from wreckage underwater and fights to survive after plane crash.
Calmly tends to Phil's scalp wound by taking off his shirt, dipping it in water, and pressing it to the injury.
Looks around carefully, scanning the surface for dangers and conditions.
Opens raft pocket and takes inventory of supplies including food, water, and survival tools.
Divides scarce food ration carefully despite difficult circumstances, following instructions on packet.
Refuses to accept defeat or panic despite Mac's despair and panic-stricken statements.
Tells Mac to 'Shut up' and enforces confidence in a situation of high stress.
Gives a tin of water sparingly to Mac, showing care for sharing resources.
Holds the compress to Phil’s head while he sleeps, showing tenderness and concern.
Responds positively to Phil’s expression of gladness, indicating mutual support and friendliness.
Struggles with his own frustration but continues trying to attract help (waves, uses dye, fires flare gun) to save the group.
Holds the compress to Phil’s head carefully, watches and tracks the dark shape under the water cautiously, demonstrating alertness and calm in uncertainty.
Recognizes the plane overhead, immediately signals for help by waving, using dye and firing flare gun to increase chances of rescue.
Momentarily strikes himself as stupid for initially just waving arms before using dye and flare gun, showing self-awareness but also initial lack of strategic signaling.
Does not get angry at Mac despite Mac’s apparent neglect and shock, restrains himself from making the situation worse.
Carefully checks provisions and water to ensure survival chances for all.
Approaches Mac with concern and tries to communicate rather than scolding or blaming him for the lost chocolate.
Throws flare gun in frustration, then quickly recovers by picking up trash and searching for supplies, checking water tins methodically.
Momentarily panics and calls out to Mac, showing distress but then restrains anger and acts pragmatically.
Appears unsure what to do next after assessing the situation and sits down quietly.
Snaps neck of albatross to obtain food for survival.
Encourages others to try eating the albatross despite their hesitation and discomfort.
Passes the pilot fish he caught and ate to others, sharing scarce food.
Passes the fish he caught to the others even though they don't like it, recognizing their need for food.
Invites Phil to his house and offers that his mother will cook for him, sharing warmth and friendship.
Realizes Mac is distressed and tries to distract him by talking and telling stories to keep spirits up.
Keeps talking to maintain morale on the raft, emphasizing the importance of staying mentally strong.
Pulls out a picture of his family and shows deep emotion, indicating vulnerability and sincere affection.
Passes raw fish to others to eat despite their reluctance, recognizing the necessity of nourishment.
Keeps the group’s morale up by distracting a distressed companion with descriptions of home and food, helping maintain mental sharpness.
Acknowledges the importance of mental resilience and camaraderie in survival.
Becomes emotionally overwhelmed by looking at the family picture and must put it away before crying.
Engages Phil in a thoughtful conversation about faith and survival, showing openness and vulnerability.
Prays aloud, expressing a sincere plea and a promise to dedicate his life if saved.
Prays earnestly for survival and promises to dedicate his life if saved.
Engages in thoughtful conversation about faith and existence with companions, showing reflection.
Louie removes Phil’s bandage, makes a lightly humorous comment to ease discomfort.
Works collaboratively with Phil and Mac to catch and kill a shark to provide food.
Silently endures suffering with others, each lost in private thoughts.
Rips open the pump sheath to make a canvas bowl to collect rainwater, showing resourcefulness and problem-solving under pressure.
Pounces on a shark, grabs its tail, and participates in killing it by stabbing its eye with a screwdriver, demonstrating courage, decisiveness, and practical skill in a life-threatening situation.
Removes Phil’s bandage despite the unpleasant smell, showing attentiveness and care for his companion’s health.
Threw the bloody bandage overboard but likely did not anticipate that the smell would attract sharks, indicating partial lack of foresight regarding the consequences of that action.
Loads and fires flares and signals the plane persistently, tries multiple methods to attract attention.
Immediately helps fellow survivors back onto the raft despite exhaustion.
Slides back into the dangerous water to try to help the weaker Phil escape despite ongoing gunfire.
Continues signaling the plane which eventually opens fire instead of rescuing them.
Climbs back into the raft to continue helping after a shark attack, works on patching holes on the raft to save all three men.
Calls out to and encourages Phil and Mac during the dangerous situation.
Makes an informal, friendly comment praising Mac's defense against sharks, expressing camaraderie.
Takes over the pumping duty to help the others survive.
Encourages Mac to stay engaged by quizzing him, showing care for his mental state.
Comforts Mac and physically embraces him along with Phil despite their own weakness.
Participates respectfully in the ritual of laying Mac out in a comfortable position and pushing his body off the raft.
Takes over the pumping duties on the raft, showing active participation and endurance despite dire physical state.
Engages Mac and Phil in quizzing and conversation to keep spirits up and minds alert despite extreme exhaustion.
Acknowledges the likely death of Mac honestly and prepares to give Mac a dignified farewell.
Remains physically weakened, barely able to speak or move, indicating severely diminished capacity but maintains responsibility for caring for others.
Does not attempt to seek immediate rescue or demonstrate any overt strategizing but continues to sustain minimal needed actions to survive and support companions.
Looks compassionately at Phil, noticing his frailty and emaciation.
Fights to stay conscious and interacts weakly with Phil, showing connection even in dire circumstances.
Despite extreme emaciation and near unconsciousness, he fights to keep his eyes open and focus, demonstrating persistence and mental alertness under dire conditions.
Attempts to communicate with Phil, showing presence of mind and situational awareness even when physically compromised.
Moment of weakness implied in physical frailty and near loss of consciousness, indicating limits to his physical competence in this scene.
Shows concern for Phil by calling out to him and asking if he's okay, listens attentively during Phil's ordeal.
Takes scrupulous care in removing maggots from the food before eating it, indicating self-respect and a degree of hopefulness despite harsh conditions.
Withdraws into himself, sitting limply with head sunk below shoulders, showing vulnerability but not hostility or bitterness.
Attempts to answer questions truthfully despite danger and hesitation.
Asks about the fate of Marines from Makin Island, showing concern for others.
Blank and hesitant under pressure; does not attempt to deceive or manipulate.
Does not try to ingratiate or negotiate with captors despite threat.
Attempts to answer the Japanese officer's questions carefully, but pauses or states he does not know some details, showing caution and limited information.
Recognizes his own photo at the table and acknowledges it, demonstrating awareness and composure under pressure.
Answers technical question about how to work the bombsight with a clear, if minimal, explanation, indicating some technical knowledge and calmness.
Asks about the fate of the Marines from Makin Island, showing initiative and concern, but the question is ignored, indicating limited control over the interaction.
Continues to draw calmly despite hearing that the Marines were beheaded, showing composure and respect.
Scratches a message on the wall bearing the names of the nine Marines, indicating remembrance and honor.
Presses his face against the wall seemingly trying to connect with Phil, showing longing and emotional connection.
Draws the Nawdn bombsight on a wet page despite difficulty and under pressure.
Uses creative communication to leave a message on the prison cell wall.
Hesitates briefly before drawing the bombsight but overcomes hesitation.
Stares at the wall, reflecting on the fate of the Marines—shows internal focus but no immediate action.
Fights aggressively to avoid being led to his death, showing resistance and courage.
Stays close to fellow prisoner Phil after being cleaned up, providing silent companionship.
Refuses to walk to his death and fights aggressively against guards trying to drag him out.
Hesitates briefly when ordered to kneel and is taken down by a strike to the knees.
Maintains physical resistance and mental defiance under extreme fear despite expecting execution.
Holds onto Phil tightly, fighting hard not to be separated despite their hands being tied.
Calls out to Phil anxiously after being separated, showing concern.
Attempts to see the world around him despite blindfold, makes light comment about wanting to come to Tokyo.
Fights hard to hold onto Phil, showing determination and presence of mind in a stressful situation.
Attempts to look under his blindfold to gather information about their surroundings.
Asks Tinker if they are in Tokyo and states 'I made it' with confidence.
No notable actions showing skill or failure during processing at POW camp; remains compliant during roll call.
Does not look at The Bird initially, head lowered, eyes cast down out of caution or fear.
Looks The Bird in the eye and shows defiance despite threat of violence.
Restrains himself from hitting back The Bird despite being struck and enraged.
Smiles a little at the Scots' secret plundering despite tension.
Looks around for The Bird, senses his presence though he can't see him, showing awareness and attentiveness toward others.
Observes Commander Fitzgerald's welcoming smile and nod, indicating openness to friendly connection.
No explicit actions or statements in this excerpt demonstrating personal warmth positively or negatively.
Notices Commander Fitzgerald's confident leadership and acknowledges a leader's presence with a welcoming smile and nod.
Looks around carefully for the Bird despite not seeing him, sensing the Bird's presence lurking in the shadows.
Feels unnerved by not knowing the Bird's location, indicating vigilance but also anxiety.
Raises his hand to identify himself as the Olympic athlete, openly acknowledges his identity.
Continues to push himself to finish the race despite being weak and sick, showing determination and resilience.
Does not retaliate or show bitterness when The Bird orders a beating after the race.
Volunteers to race despite being emaciated and weak.
Runs well initially and pushes himself toward the finish line despite illness and weakness.
Fails to win the race, collapsing and unable to keep up due to physical condition.
Shows strong fighting spirit and determination in face of physical limitations and verbal abuse.
Helps steal a newspaper for information.
Uses sharpened bamboo reeds with others to steal sugar for the group.
Carries buckets of sewage with Fitzgerald and smiles despite the unpleasant task, sharing a moment of silent camaraderie.
Helps steal a newspaper for information.
Uses hollow bamboo reeds with sharpened edges to steal sugar by piercing sacks and collecting sugar in socks and pant legs.
Carries heavy buckets of sewage slowly and confidently across the yard while maintaining a calm demeanor despite being watched by guards.
Pauses and looks thoughtfully out at the ocean during a difficult moment.
Observes Harris being beaten without intervening to avoid making things worse.
Feels intense anger toward The Bird and contemplates killing him but ultimately embraces Fitzgerald's advice to survive rather than retaliate violently.
Automatically tries to hide at the back of the barrack when guards enter, avoiding confrontation.
Does not retaliate or respond with anger after being hit by The Bird; remains silent and endures the pain.
Automatically heads for the back of the barrack to be hidden when guards enter, showing quick, instinctive response.
Does not meet The Bird’s eyes when confronted, possibly showing fear or unwillingness to engage directly.
Recovers slowly after being struck, pulling himself upright despite pain, showing resilience and physical capability.
Wants to tell family he is not dead; considers delivering a message of love to his mother.
Stares at The Bird in confusion and hatred, wanting to kill him but does not act on it.
Takes in the radio men’s message but does not immediately understand why it is happening; shows confusion and internal conflict.
Hesitates but agrees to speak using his own words on Radio Tokyo broadcast despite uncertain circumstances.
Broadcasts a reassuring radio message to his family, expressing care and hope to maintain connections despite hardship.
Mentions family members and shared future plans (hunting with dad, mom's cooking), showing personal affection and warmth.
Appears cautious and somewhat disoriented at first, indicating vulnerability and sincerity in his communication.
Leans cautiously into the microphone and speaks calmly and clearly on the radio to his family, despite being in a disorienting and stressful situation.
Imagines his family receiving the message, showing emotional awareness but maintains composure while communicating.
Begins the radio communication tentatively, indicating some uncertainty but still takes initiative to maintain contact.
Refuses to read a scripted propaganda broadcast that dishonestly praises America, despite pressure and opportunity for easier treatment.
Encourages another prisoner to punch him in the face to save another man from beating.
Remains calm and defiant when forced to be punished by other prisoners, mentally steels himself for the ordeal.
Encourages a prisoner to punch him to get it over with quickly, showing controlled acceptance and strategic endurance.
Appears unable to prevent or resist punishment, physically vulnerable and at the mercy of captors and fellow prisoners.
Encourages the next prisoner to take the punishment, yelling with a mouth full of blood, displaying resilience and defiance.
Spits on a soldier (enemy) during punishment.
Maintains eye contact with The Bird amidst brutal punishment, showing courage and unwillingness to submit but little indication of warmth towards captors.

Gazes darkly during a lighthearted performance by fellow prisoners and Japanese soldiers, thinking of his tormentor and Kano's gun, suggesting internal bitterness and lack of friendly or tolerant feelings.
Continues to face brutal physical punishment, endures severe beatings without breaking or surrendering.
Yells defiantly at captors even while bloodied and beaten, displaying mental resilience and psychological strength.
Spits on a soldier despite receiving violent punishment, an act of defiance showing courage but potentially risking harsher consequences.
Does not attempt to escape or resist physically but focuses on surviving punishment, showing a measured and strategic endurance.
Internalizes fear and pain, shown by his dark mood and troubling thoughts in the background moments, indicating emotional struggle but not loss of control.
Nods in silence to The Bird's announcement despite disbelief, showing restraint and avoidance of conflict.
Remains silent and shows no visible reaction when The Bird, his brutal tormentor, announces his promotion and impending departure, managing his emotions carefully in a tense situation.
Internally feels fear and flinches when The Bird whispers in his ear, showing a natural, human reaction to intimidation but maintaining composure afterwards.
Watches over fellow prisoners during air raid, alert and responsive to danger.
Struggles silently to figure a way out of their situation without showing panic or selfishness.
Climbs onto the barracks roof with others to observe the air battle, stays alert to situation.
Struggles internally to figure out a way out of the nightmare situation but no immediate plan emerges.
Responds quickly to command to drop to the ground and protect himself from explosion.
Sits up and looks around despite exhaustion and difficult conditions, showing awareness of surroundings.
Does not take overt action to resist or attempt escape when led away; follows the movement with others.
Feels and recognizes the pain of a woman locking eyes with him, demonstrating emotional intelligence but no overt problem-solving or action.
Keeps composure despite extreme physical suffering and humiliation, unable to meet antagonist's eye but does not retaliate or complain.
Shows vulnerability and despair inwardly (knees buckle, wants to shoot himself) but continues to support fellow POW Tinker, allowing leaning on him.
Wears tropical weight khakis in a freezing camp, showing lack of preparation for harsh conditions.
Physically weak and unable to stand without support; knees buckle at sight of The Bird, indicating a momentary collapse of confidence under extreme stress.
Despite extreme starvation and physical hardship, manages to survive arrival at an even harsher POW camp, indicating resilience though not direct competence in this excerpt.
Continues working carrying heavy coal despite harsh conditions and witness of a fellow POW's death.
Shows no visible reaction or emotional response to the death of a fellow POW, continuing as if nothing happened.
Notices the instability of the plank while carrying heavy coal, indicating awareness of danger.
Hauls the heavy coal up a narrow plank and stairs 50 feet above ground despite difficult conditions.
Continues working without hesitation after witnessing a POW fall to his death, showing numbness rather than hesitation or panic.
No reaction to The Bird announcing President Roosevelt's death; emotionally shut down and silent.
Feels deep personal despair alone after being pushed and injured; bows head and weeps privately.
Continues working under extreme physical and psychological hardship despite severe injury and exhaustion.
Falls due to weakness and guard’s push, resulting in a debilitating leg injury that ends his dreams of running.
Shows no outward reaction to devastating news (President Roosevelt's death), indicating emotional numbness rather than proactive response.
Lowers his head and breathes deeply to center himself before lifting the plank, showing inner focus and resolve.
Struggles visibly and suffers under punishment but keeps going, revealing endurance rather than warmth.
Does not respond or engage with others who ask if he is alright, showing emotional withdrawal.
After years of abuse, Louie finally looks The Bird in the eye defiantly, inspiring fellow POWs and raising their spirits.
Maintains eye contact with The Bird, defies him by holding the heavy plank despite brutal punishment, inspiring other POWs.
Eventually collapses after being physically overwhelmed and hit repeatedly by The Bird.
Endures brutal physical abuse without retaliating or showing bitterness.
Maintains silent composure with other POWs amidst suspicion and distrust.
Endures repeated physical abuse without giving up or showing defeat.
Continues running and pushing forward despite severe exhaustion and injuries.
Shows no immediate reaction of panic or hysteria during The Bird’s assault.
Does not organize or lead others during the POW moments portrayed here; largely passive in this excerpt.
Seems physically overwhelmed and incapacitated without counteraction during the beating.
Looks at the faces of other men as they are led through the tunnel, acknowledging their shared hardship.
Wades into the river near fellow POWs, sharing the vulnerable experience of bathing under guard’s watch.
Stands with fellow POWs silently and motionless facing the guards, showing solidarity and mutual support.
Braces himself to die alongside other POWs, displaying courage but no explicit warmth or connection beyond shared fate.
Wades cautiously into the river while observing the guards' threatening posture, indicating awareness and prudence.
Stands motionless and focused alongside fellow POWs when the guards watch them menacingly, showing controlled composure under threat.
Braces himself to face the oncoming American bomber, prepared for death, showing mental readiness and acceptance of circumstances.
Sinks to his knees, covers his face, overwhelmed by survival and emotion
Jays out in the water and opens his arms in a victorious gesture
Is absent from the communal celebrations and feasting, preferring solitude
Carefully and slowly enters The Bird's empty office alone
Stands paralyzed, unsure how to react upon learning the war is over; sinks to his knees and covers his face.
Swims back in the water and opens his arms as if crossing a finish line, symbolizing a personal victory and survival.
Disappears from the group and carefully, slowly enters The Bird’s abandoned office, showing cautiousness and deliberate action.
Allows the situation—the escape of The Bird—to sink in without immediate reactive action.
Runs directly to Louise, enfolds her in his arms, and holds tightly with Anthony, showing mutual comfort and tears.
Shares a smile with Pete, displaying friendly rapport and connection.
Returns to Japan to find and make peace with former captors, motivated by forgiveness and faith.
Smiles and waves warmly at Japanese people and children cheering him on.
Runs in the Olympics at age 80, holding the Olympic torch high with a beaming face, engaging positively with the crowd.
